document_title: Mitral valve stenosis: Causes, signs, complications and prevention
subsection_name: hep-van-hai-la.json_8_How is mitral valve stenosis diagnosed?
subsection_content:
To accurately diagnose mitral valve stenosis, the doctor will ask about your condition, examine you, use a stethoscope to listen to your heart, listen to your lungs, and conduct tests. Paraclinical methods include:
Echocardiography: is a means to help determine the diagnosis of mitral valve stenosis.; Transesophageal echocardiography: similar to endoscopy, inserting the probe into the esophagus to more thoroughly examine the images that transthoracic echocardiography is limited in examining.; Electrocardiogram: determines heart rate and arrhythmias, or an exercise electrocardiogram will be needed to see the heart's response to exercise.; Chest X-ray: examine enlarged heart and pulmonary congestion; Cardiac catheterization: depending on the condition, this is not a mandatory indication.
In addition, doctors can perform tests and diagnose other diseases to determine the condition of heart valve disease, to help find appropriate treatment for each specific patient.
Figure A: Mitral valve stenosis on 3D echocardiography
